cab.content: Colonel W. Dally Jones.SECRET.ocument Is the Property ofMINISTRY OF FOOlr-AU S^ort for Week ending Wednesday, December 11, 1918, Mr. Clynes has addressed a letter to the Chairmen of Pood Control Committeesthroughout the country. In this letter Mr. Clynes expresses the confident hope thathis successor, whoever lie may be, will not maintain the present restrictions a daylonger than the public interest demands. At the same time he reminds the Com-mittees that the worlds food supply must still for a time give ground for anxiety,and that.in large territories of Europe there is a danger of famine this winter. Itwill, therefore, clearly be necessary at least during the coming winter and spring tocontinue the main safeguards for a just and equal distribution of our food supplies which the necessities of the war have led us to establish. Mr. Clynes appealsthrough the Committees to the public to show as willing a spirit in supportingthese necessary safeguards as they have shown in their maintenance during the yearsof war. The Food Council. At their meeting on December 5th, the Food Council passed a hearty vote of congratulation to the Chairman, Mr. Clynes, on his unopposed returnto Parliament. After receiving the report of the Sub-Committee appointed to consider thequestion of differential rates for milk production the Council have recommended andMr. Clynes has approved that a travelling Commission should be appointed with thefollowing terms of reference : " To report upon the costs of milk production in various areas of Great Britain during winter and summer periods and upon the different methods of production prevalent in different areas, and upon the approximate quantities of milk produced at different times of the year in those areas by each method of production." In view of representations made by the Milk Control Board the Council haveagreed that Messrs. Nestle's use of liquid milk must be subordinated to the liquid milk requirements of London and other parts of the country in the event of serious shortage. The Council received a report from Sir Alan Anderson that he had consultedwith the Treasury and found that they attached very great importance to starting our export trade in tea at the earliest possible moment. It has been decided that customers may have an opportunity of changing theirretailers during the second fortnight in January. After considering a memorandum by the Chairman of the Royal' Commissionon the Sugar Supply the Council agreed to an increased distribution of sugar asfollows: (1) Manufacturers to be allowed 50 per cent, of their 1915 sugar allowance as from December 29th (an increase of 74,000 tons). (2) The allowance of sugar in catering establishments to be raised from l/7th to 3/l4ths oz. per meal as from December 29th. By an amendment of the Rationing Order caterers to be entitled to use their stocks to provide this amount for their customers for Christmas (an increase of 5,000 tons). (3) The domestic ration to he raised from 8 ozs. to 12 ozs., as from February 1st (an increase of 232,000 tons). (4) 90,000 tons of sugar to be provided for jam-making between January 1st and May 31st. This amount is to be taken as an instalment of the 180,000 tons estimated as the jam allotment for the year, the amount of the issue for the period after May 31st to be reconsidered if an increase appeared necessary. The Imports Board. The Chairman reported he had been instructed by the FoodCouncil to inform the Imports Board that the present arrangements for obtainingcredit from the "United States for purchases would cease on the conclusion of peace. A (33)7008-2 Pk9 145 12/18 I&S A.PART I.-ACTION TAKEN. Negotiations are taking place with the Trade Commissioner for the Union ofSouth. Africa as to the purchase of the available supplies of eggs, estimated at 12,500long cases. An application has been forwarded to the Treasury for sanction for the purchaseof 25,000 tons of cotton cake from Egypt. The Board have agreed (a) that the Foreign Of nee should be pressed for a freemarket to be allowed to the trade for the purchase of lemons from Italy; (b) that thepurchase of 10,000 tons of oranges by the Orange Commission on behalf of theMinistry, be proceeded with; (c) that the Ministry should press for the removal of import restrictions on oranges from all sources. The Board have decided -that in view of the cold storage position they aredebarred from purchasing Canadian frozen fish. The Consumers Council. The Council considered and approved the proposal to renew this country's tea export trade. The draft interim report of the Legalisation of Improvements Sub-Committeerecently appointed by the Council was considered. It was decided that the report should go forward at once with the exception of resolutions 5 and 6 (relating respec-tively to the exhibition of prices in shops and national kitchens) which were referred back to the Sub-Committee. The following resolutions put forward in the report were accepted by theCouncil: Resolution 1. We strongly request that the Food Controller impress upon the Government and Parliament the necessity of continuing, in the form of permanent legislation, the regulations made by him relating to the sale by nett weight of the following articles : Tea, bread, jam, beans, peas and pulse, wheat, rye, oats and barley, potatoes, canned meat, horse mixtures and poultry mixtures and cattle feeding-stuffs (other than wet brewers' and distillers' grains). Resolution 2. (a) The Sub-Committee approves of the regulations laid down by the Food Controller prescribing certain standards of quality for the following articles :-Compound lard, vegetable butter, vegetable lard, shredded suet, dripping, jam, cocoa powder, and margarine. The Sub-Committee are of opinion, that such regulations be maintained in the form of permanent legislation. (6) With regard to margarine the Sub-Committee suggest that the first and second standard of margarine should be certified by Government analysis and imprimatur and no other margarine should be allowed to be sold. (c) With regard to sausages the existing standards are: (i) Sausages containing not less than 67 per cent, of meat or pork; and (ii) Sausages con- taining not less than 50 per cent, meat or pork ; and the Sub-Committee suggest that no other sausages should be allowed to be sold. Resolution 3. We approve of the work (in relation to milk control) being done by the Food Controller, and are of opinion that it is absolutely necessary to exercise national and municipal control over the supply and distribution of milk, Resolution 4.-In the opinion of this Sub-Committee it is desirable that the testing process embodied in the Testing of Seeds Order be made part of the permanent legislation of the country, and, if possible, extended. Resolution 7. (a) The effectiveness and beneficial results of control (including control of transport) have been manifest in keeping the price of commodities at a reasonable level to the consumer, and the Sub-Committee will accordingly go more fully into the whole matter with a view to bringing definite proposals before the Consumers' Council for the co-ordination of the different departments affecting the well-being of the people. (b) That this Sub-Committee, while strongly in favour of abrogating forthwith all the measures which have been enacted under the Defence of the Realm Act in restriction of personal freedom of every kind, expresses its opinion that it would be a great misfortune to the country if the admirable service rendered by the Ministry of Food and its various committees were put an end to, the Sub-Committee being firmly convinced that co-ordination in production and distribution under central control has proved exceedingly advantageous to the whole community during the war, and will prove equally to their advantage in time of peace. This policy should therefore be continued and developed as part of the national interest. SUPPLIES. Bacon and Hams. The demand for bacon and hams is still reduced, and thereare clear indications that the stocks available are more than ample to meet requirements. It is proposed to make arrangements for the export to Ireland of the surplusstocks of fat backs and bellies in the hands of wholesalers and retailers in this country,as there is a good market in Ireland for fat bacon. The shipments of bacon and hamsfrom Ireland are larger than was expected, but the quality is excellent and there is a ready market for everything that arrives. It will be necessary to provide a profit forthe English wholesaler if these shipments continue after the 1st January 1919. Cereals. In response to a question raised at a conference of Divisional FoodCommissioners as to how long the bread subsidy would be necessary, Sir AlanAnderson said that it would, he thought, be required until the reduction in the price ofwheat allowed of the production by bakers of the quartern loaf at 9d. At present when made with Australian wheat, which is the cheapest in the market, the loaf worksout at $\d., while if "made with American wheat it costs Is. 6d Dried Fruits. Further purchases of Indian sultanas are being made to secure the900 tons required to complete the quantity sanctioned by the Treasury. On account of the lateness of the season, the Persian dates will not arrive until january or February 1919. Feeding Stuff's.-It appears from the reports received by the Live Stock Commis-sioners that, generally speaking, farmers are now receiving feeding-stuffs under theDistribution Scheme. The delay still experienced in certain localities is due in somecases to difficulties with railway companies; in other cases the problem has beensolved by the transfer of orders from one Port Committee to another. Difficulties have also arisen, especially in the Hull area, with regard to the distri-bution of millers' offals, although it is reported that practically all the farmers arein fact obtaining the supplies they need. Interviews have been held with representa-tives of the millers, and it is expected that the various local millers' associations will undertake, when occasion arises, to secure that supplies are provided for all personsentitled to receive them under the Order. Meat. The situation with regard to meat supplies has developed in a way that was not anticipated. The effect of the increased price for cattle whichoperated from the first of the month has been most marked, and it appears that aconsiderable quantity of beasts were held back in order to derive the benefit of this increase. Concurrently with this, the arrivals of imported meat have been extremelyheavy, and, as the demand continnes to be satisfied to a very large extent with home-killed meat, the output of frozen meat has been less than was desired, and a positionof acute pressure on the cold storage space has arisen. The Live Stock Commissionershave been placed in a difficult position. On the one hand, they have been requestedto make the largest issue possible of frozen meat in order to relieve the stores, andon the other hand, the farmers continue to pour in large quantities of stock andresent any restrictions being placed upon their offerings. The measure of restrictionwhich has been placed upon the shipments from Ireland has not been sufficient to relieve the situation. As an instance of this, it may be mentioned that 2,000 cattlewere awaiting slaughter at Birkenhead at the end of last week, and it became necessary to order that this meat should be sent to London. The arrangements forthe issue of frozen meat were therefore dislocated to a certain extent. At the presentmoment the stores are absolutely full, and vessels are in port awaiting discharge.Considerable doubt is expressed by the Commissioners as to whether the extraration about to be issued will be taken by the public. It is reported from many partsof the country that prices are still too high for the industrial classes to take full advantage of this concession, and it appears probable that the public demand will bein the direction of requiring lower prices before there is any strong appeal forincreased rations. It is intended to release canned meats from coupon restrictions. ORDERS UNDER DEFENCE OF THE REALM REGULATIONS. (1) The Canned Fish (Retail Prices and Distribution) Order, 1918, dated 5thDecember 1918, fixes maximum retail prices for certain kinds of canned fish.Norwegian brisling, mausse or sild, and canned salmon are at present included in the schedule, but other varieties may be added. The Order requires the containers to belabelled, aud prices to be exhibited. (2) The Seed Potatoes Order, dated 5th December 1918. provides that on a saleof seed potatoes, a written declaration shall be furnished to the buyer stating the class,variety, and dressing of the potatoes sold. Tlie price is not fixed. (3) An Order dated 1th December 1918, revokes the Cake and Pastry Order, 1917,and clause 2 of the Sugar (Confectionery) Order, 1917, thereby abolishing therestrictions on the making of fancy pastry, crumpets, muffins, and tea-cakes, andalso the rules as to the materials which may be used in cakes, buns, scones, andbiscuits. ENFORCEMENT OF ORDERS. The total number of prosecutions recorded in the past week is 762 with 695convictions. The greatest number of summonses were issued under the following Orders : the rationing Order 1918 with 178 cases; the Flour (Restriction) Order (Ireland) with63 cases ; the Bacon, Ham and Lard (Prices) Order with 55 cases ; the Flour andBread (Prices) Order 1917 with 49 cases. It is noticeable that the Orders quoted above appear regularly in the list of orders under which the greatest number of summonses have been issued, indicating thatthere is comparatively little variation in the class of offence prevalent from week to week. PART II.-SUMMARY OF THE FOOD POSITION. IMPORTS. In the week ended December 7th the imports of the principal foods and feeding-stuffs (182,400 tons) again barely reached the weekly average of the first 49 weeks of 1918 (181,600 tons) or of the first 14 weeks of the cereal year (181,800 tons). Wheat imports were good (111,400 tons as equivalent grain) as also were theimports of oats (15,900 tons), meat (15,700 tons), bacon (12,200 tons), condensed milk(3,700 tons), butter (1,800 tons), eggs (1,900 tons), and onions (2,600 tons). Importsof maize (3,600 tons) and barley (700 tons) were again low. Imports of sugar fell to,700 tons, but the stocks (381,000 tons) are high. Another large import of tea(5,400 tons) is recorded and the stocks are rising rapidly ; on 30th November teastocks in bond (61,600 tons) were the highest during the past six years, and thenet imports in November (27,200 tons) were exceeded only in the month ofDecember 1914. The November imports of oilseeds (125,700 tons) and vegetable oil (23,000 tons)show a substantial improvement on the monthly averages in 1918 or in 1917, and areabove the average monthly imports before the war ; but only 100 tons of oilseed cakearrived. The total imports for the first 14 weeks of the cereal years 1917-18 and1918-19 are compared in the following table : Total Imports for the first 14 weeks of cereal years. 1917. 1918.' Meat. Ou present information there was a decrease of about 400 tons in civilian consumption in Great Britain in the last week of November. Issues of refrigeratedmeat rose from 1,100 tons in the preceding week to 3,000 tons, so that the decreasefalls on home-grown meat. The decrease of home supplies is explained partly by the exhaustion of surplus supplies on grazing areas, partly by the general anticipation ofthe increased prices to farmers on December 1st, and partly by the force of thetradition which leads producers to reserve their best stock for the Christmas markets.During the week there was a net addition of 200 tons to the home-grown beef andmutton placed in cold storage. Flour. The figures of millers deliveries and releases of imported flour continue toshow a steady decrease (Table B (1)). The index given in Table C (2) shows that this movement is the reverse of that of a year ago, and that the present level is nowconsiderably below that of November 1917. Fish. The improvement of supplies of fresh fish at the chief inland marketscontinued up to the 23rd November, but fell away in the last week of the month byabout 20 per cent. The same movement appeared at Billingsgate market, where,however, supplies over the month were still about 40 per cent, above those ofNovember 1916 and 1917. Jam. The ration (which was instituted on the 3rd November) necessitates a supply of 23,500 tons a month for civilian consumption. The output by licensed jammanufacturers in November amounted to about 23,200 tons, as compared with 24,300tons in October. The quantity was less than was anticipated owing to the non-arrival of any considerable cargoes of oranges until the end of the month. Stocks were reduced from 26,200 tons on 31st October to about 22,300 tons on 30th November or4 weeks' requirements. Pulp stocks were reduced, by 9,500 tons, but the remainingstocks of jam and pulp expressed as equivalent jam were still equal to about 13 weeks'ration requirements, and the position should improve with the increasing imports oforanges which, amounted to 3,500 tons in the week ended November 30th, and to4,800 tons in the week ended December 7th. STOCKS. Compared with the stocks a year ago those on the 1st December 1918 showsubstantial increases with very few exceptions, notably oilseeds (29 per cent, decrease)and oil cake (19 per cent, decrease). There have also been decreases in the stocks of coffee (40 per cent, decrease) and cocoa (60 per cent, decrease), but they are stillgreatly in excess of the pre-war stocks. Wheat stocks are higher than those of a yearago by 25 per cent., and other cereals and pulses by 11 per cent. Stocks of butter(8,500 tons) and cheese (26,600 tons) which have been subjected to a seasonaldecrease are 66 per cent, and 45 per cent., respectively, above those of last year.Stocks of bacon and lard, of which there was a shortage last year, have been increasedfive or six fold. Compared with the stocks on 1st November substantial additions were made tothe stocks of meat (30,100 tons increase), tea (11,100 tons increase), and oilseeds(37,500 tons increase). Stocks which were drawn upon heavily during Novemberinclude sugar (33,000 tons decrease), bacon (19,200 tons decrease), and condensed milk (6,100 tons decrease). The quantity of bacon stored by the Ministry of Food onDecember 7th amounted to only 20,000 tons, the maximum quantity stored havingbeen 82,100 tons in August. On the other hand the storage of lard by the Ministry(29,400 tons on 7th December) stands at its maximum. TABLE A..-IMPORTS OF PRINCIPAL FOOD AND FEEDING STUFFS. .Article. 1. STOCKS of the PRINCIPAL FOODS and FEEDING STUFFS in the UNITED KINGDOM. The figures for. wheat and Hour include stocks in port granaries and warehouses, inland warehouses,mills, and bakers' shops, as well as estimated stocks on farms ; those for barley, oats, beans, and peasinclude stocks in port granaries and warehouses and in mills, in maltsters' hands, and estimated farm stocks ;those for maize, rice, and grain meals include stocks in port granaries and warehouses and in mills. The figures for sugar are stocks in possession of the Sugar Commission ; those for butttr, margarine,lard, cheose, condensed milk, meat, and fish include stocks at ports, in cold stores, and in importers' andwholesalers' warehouses.
